Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Printing Innovative Nano Technology Research and Elite Education (PINE TREE) Program

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NUE in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Printing Innovative Nano Technology Research and Elite Education (PINE TREE) Program", at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), under the direction of Dr. Namsoo Kim, will be a supplemental program for the Printing Nano Engineering (PNE) concentration option available at UTEP beginning in the Fall of 2014. The goal of this proposal is to design and implement a 24-credit-hour PNE concentration (with opportunities for international experiences) under the Bachelor of Science in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering (MME) program, which will prepare graduates for advanced, high-tech engineering and manufacturing careers in printed electronics. The PINE TREE Program has established three objectives to achieve its goal: 1) Recruit and prepare lower-division pre-engineering students to pursue a career option in Nanotechnology. 2) Modify, evaluate, and refine upper-division PNE courses to ensure that students are prepared to enter careers in printing nano-engineering. The strategic actions include the assessing and evaluating of the upper-division curricula and refining courses based on assessment results. 3) Integrate research and development into undergraduate education to reinforce the concepts acquired in the PNE curricula. The PINE TREE program builds on nano-scale and pedagogical research that is already established at UTEP, as well as on the newly established program between UTEP and Seokyeong University (SKU) in Seoul, South Korea that offers upper-division PNE courses to SKU students who transfer to UTEP in their junior year. This international collaboration between UTEP and SKU will help advance PNE education in the U.S. and has the potential of serving as a model which can be replicated by other universities and strengthen the U.S. global manufacturing position.

The students who complete the PINE TREE program will be experts in the field of printed electronics and able to manufacture printed electronics in the areas of printable material development, system manufacturing, and development of flexible electronics. Since the UTEP MME Department has an undergraduate student population that is 81% Hispanic and 31% Female, the PINE TREE Program will create a diverse group of engineers with the skills and qualifications needed in industry for printed electronics; the students will be diverse not only in ethnicity and gender, but in educational background. The program also features international collaborations that will help advance PNE education in the U.S.

Institution.Name: University of Texas at El Paso
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas at El Paso

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lower-division pre-engineering students in Metallurgical, Materials and Bioengineering Department at UTEP have been recruited and prepared to pursue a career option in Printing Nano-Engineering (PNE). The PNE concentration courses  are prepared through this NSF NUE program and it provided students with a better understanding of nano-printable materials, printing processes, and 3D printing design. The students have acquired the foundational knowledge and skills necessary to complete the PNE concentration courses. They have developed the ability to synthesize various types of printable materials and the ability to choose the proper processes for manufacturing printed electronics through the newly created PNE courses. The PNE courses also have provided the required skills to operate the proper machines for analysis of the properties of materials and specimens. Knowing how these printing technologies can be applied to practical industries allows the students to determine their future career in the fields of 3D printing, printable materials, printed electronics, and bio printing. The PNE Program has created a diverse group of engineers from diverse ethnicities and educational backgrounds, with the skills and qualifications needed in the printing nano engineering industry. Students who have completed the PNE courses have contributed to the development of manufacturing industries. PNE Program will continue to provide undergraduate students opportunities to publish journal papers and to present their research products at international conferences. Six referee-reviewed papers have been published with PNE undergraduate students and adviser and 2 papers have been submitted. More than 10 conference papers have been presented and published in China, Korea, Mexico and US by PNE students and advisers.

The students under the PNE program can produce their own material using each different printing process; including new filaments for Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printing, metal and ceramic pastes or cookie dough for high-viscosity printing, and low-viscosity inks for flexible 2D printing. The developed materials can be used for practical applications such as manufacturing of printed electronic devices, food, and 3D design works. The student learn about the importance of evaluating and characterizing the nano-printable materials and the final products, in the PNE syllabus.  They learn the fundamental skills to operate the right machine for the specific analysis or characterization of the properties of their specimens through lectures and projects in the courses. At the end, the students are able to create copies of any 3D structure: miniatures, cellular phone covers, fossil skulls, historical palaces, symbols, logos, and clothes etc. 3D duplicates of artwork offer plenty of educational opportunities to students. . Two students have established their own shop or small company based on this PNE courses in 2016 at El Paso, TX.

Through the development of a global workforce, the program will increase the involvement of the U.S. in printing nano engineering. UTEP is already collaborating with South Korea, a leader in the field, at the upper-division level; however, until now, there were no specific courses that gave students opportunities to learn in depth about 3D printing. The expansion of the 3D printing industry into many other fields such as medical, biological, manufacturing, and construction, etc. shows its great potential to become a revolutionary technology in the near future. There have been more than 34 Students from S. Korea registered in the PNE program since 2014, and 7 students graduated under the PNE option in the MMBME department.

 

Multiple opportunities will be provide to students by PINE TREE Program at UTEP, including education through specifically created courses, hands – on experience, publication of journal papers, and attending conferences. All these experiences will result in the students becoming experts in the printing nano engineering industry, allowing UTEP to become a global leader in PNE via the PNE Program.

Modified by: Namsoo Kim

Images (1 of )
  • ABS-Cu composite filament were produced using a filament extruder, then the filaments were printed to make 3D structure, UTEP logo, by using FDM 3D printing machines.This new filaments help to print a variety of metal 3D materials
    Printing Nano Engineering
    Creative Commons
    Namsoo Kim
    3D product printed by ABS-Cu Filament
  • Figure 24 shows 3D objectives produced using 3D printing technologies. Original concept sketches were prepared by graduate level students who major in design. Conversely, the 3D CAD design and final products were manufactured by undergraduate level students, showing importance of 3D design education
    Printing Nano Engineering
    Creative Commons
    Namsoo Kim
    3D Designed Products Designed by Graduate Students
  • New filaments, including metal powders, were developed in order to manufacture metal 3D structures by FDM 3D printing process. ABS-Fe composite filament were produced using a filament extruder, then the filaments were printed to make 3D structures by using FDM 3D printing machines
    Printing Nano Engineering
    Creative Commons
    Namsoo Kim
    3D product made by ABS-Fe Filament
  • Cookies dough, one of the high-viscosity materials, can be printed using the super high-viscosity dispenser. As shown in figure , 3D cookies were printed with the help of high-viscosity dispenser and XYZ motioning stages.
    Printing Nano Engineering
    Creative Commons
    Namsoo Kim
    Printed Cookie Dough
  • Students developed flexible 2D printed circuits with a fast and simple process. The circuit can be used for varying light and sound applications and it was aimed for educational application
    Printing Nano Engineering
    Creative Commons
    Namsoo Kim
    Applications of CNT deposited circuit
  • A hat was designed by a student enrolled in the class. A 3D design of the hat was drawn using the 3D design software, Sold Works 2013. The 3D designs are shown and were printed using FDM 3D printers (CubeX Duo, 3D Systems, and NP-Mendel, Opencreators).
    Printed Nano Engineering
    Creative Commons
    Namsoo Kim
    3D Designed Hat and Printed Hat
